text: Which jobs do qualify us to speak out in the world? Where is the job training or education for that?
No one wants to hear from "celebrities" unless it's THEIR celebrity. And the fact a few of them are wealthy is somehow disqualifying.
I'm not saying anything that hasn't been said better. But I think a lot about sports a) cuz I love it and b) as it informs my own industry.
It's simple at the base level: white people just want POC to shut up and stay in the narrowest of lane--one defined by white people.
But if Charles Barkley says he's not a role model people get angry. But if Colin K. expresses free political speech people also get angry.
That many are POC and paid by rich white men make the entire arrangement an unavoidable political construct.
There is no sportless life. The men & women who play games at a high level are faces of our world...whether we or they want that or not.

text: Monday he was sent home
column4: weak and shaky. But alive and with a good prognosis. All because a nurse happened to be eating nearby.

text: ...and put him on a temp pacemaker. The next day he had surgery & a fulltime pacemaker was installed
column4: taking over for his failed electrical.

text: ...bagging my dad and giving him something to shock his heart back. They saved his life. SHE saved his life. They got him to the hospital...
She did CPR for five minutes. She did it so hard that she broke his rib. She did it until the EMTs showed up and took over...
As this happened
column4: a woman came running over from another table and said: I'm a nurse. Get him on the ground now! She then began CPR.

text: My mom and others saw it happen
column4: because he just STOPPED. They were yelling at him
column5: calling 911...but he was blue. He was GONE.

text: An hour later I find out: he's alive. But (later explained) he hadn't passed out. he'd gone into full cardiac arrest and stopped breathing.
But I knew it was bad. Whatever it was. My mom didn't call or text us for a long time. I had nothing except to follow the healthcare vote.
I texted: is he alright
column4: awake? My mom said she didn't know. So I started to freak out. A few min later she said: breathing and conscious.

text: I called my brother. We conferred. We both felt something bad was happening. Especially because my mom had gone incommunicado.
My dad has a history of health problems. Only a month ago he'd had a little heart event and had had a stent put in. So I was worried.
i texted back and she didn't respond. i called her. She picked up. i asked what had happened. She said she couldn't talk. And hung up.

column4: it said: "Your dad passed out in a restaurant. We're in an ambulance going to the hospital."

Cancer patients don't need courage. They need good health insurance and early detection. That's why I'm alive. Not because I'm tough.
But courageousness is a standard that no sick person should feel like they have to meet.
And I'm not mad at people who use the tough narrative re cancer. People want to believe there's some control when there's not.
Glorifying strength and not understanding weakness is a dangerous cultural narrative. We end up w/ toxic versions of heroism.
I used to fight with TSCC execs about what heroism was and how people should react in the face of danger/death.
Survival and morality aren't connected. Survival and courage aren't connected. Pop culture glorifies courage and lacks empathy for weakness.
I was a sobbing terrified baby. I took Ativan every fucking day until the surgery. It was isolating and debilitating.
There's no tough guy exemption. It's math and it's biology and it's luck and it's money but mostly it's biology and luck.
People don't battle cancer. Cancer stands over you like a god from the darkness and debates whether it's your time to die.
Cancer is a tough sonuvabitch. That's who's tough. It beat fucking John Wayne. it beats whoever it wants to whenever it chooses.
Cancer doesn't particularly care if you stared down the North Koreans or won the Tour De France or were the show runner of a robot show...
I wish John McCain well. Cancer sucks. But I'm not a fan of the "Cancer's met a match in this tough guy" narrative.

text: No one would ever say that. But again and again I would get coded critiques that led me to that conclusion.
Pretty soon I began to believe that their Qs were just code for: "Isn't he a little gay?"
Many of these Qs are ridiculous for a 17yrold actor who didn't have to be any of those things for a long time in the story.
..or: "Does he really feel like the future leader of the free world?" "Is he a leader of men?" "Is he a romantic lead?"
...but when we'd ask their reasoning they'd always say something like: "we aren't sure he feels like a leading man"...
We did but kept insisting that TD was awesome and we weren't going to find anyone better. This isn't uncommon in casting...
One problem: Fox didn't agree w/ us. It wasn't that they didn't like him
column4: but they had doubts and wanted us to keep looking.

column4: the EAA has also been used to keep gay-straight alliances and atheist groups from being forced out of schools.

text: In the years since
column4: many more conservative school boards have used the EAA to give Bible study groups access to public institutions.

text: We had to testify in front of the County school board
column4: arguing our positions. 16 years old. The board refused the group's petition

text: I received a lot of "outside" pressure to "play nice" and allow the groups to use the school grounds. It was terrifying.
The next thing I knew
column4: I was a 16yrold from Boulder
column5: CO on the front page of the Washington Post and the Rocky Mountain News...

text: A few friends & I decided to push back against it. We didn't realize at the time we were the first school board in country to take this up..
...the president of our student body led the movement to ask the school board to enforce the act
column4: or close the non-curriculum groups...

text: ...such as chess club or astronomy club were allowed to use school facilities. The law was lobbied for by conservative christian groups...
The EEA was designed to force public schools into allowing bible groups to use the facilities if the schools allowed non-curricular groups..
I was in high school when a Christian student group lobbied the school board to enforce Reagan's new Equal Access Act...

text: @steveasbell You're the exception to all the rules Steve.
A writer who oeven entertains that he or she has a right to ask this question is what we in the entertainment business call "difficult."
The Q always becomes w/ an exec: whose story are we trying to tell? Are you trying to help me tell mine? Or expect me to tell yours?
Doesn't mean i'm always right. Or that I always make things people like. And certainly it causes me a lot of trouble. But I don't care.
My personal superpower and my professional kryptonite are the same thing: I am genetically incapable of not telling my story.
You soon find a crisis point: are u being paid to tell YOUR story or A story? Only 1 has a chance to be great. But either can be successful.
But there are obvious problems there: a personal idiosyncratic story puts execs at a disadvantage. They can't manage for that.
It's why I like tv more than film. Over time
column4: more JOSH gets into the things I do. Hopefully more of me is better. I have to believe that.

text: I have a hard time writing well unless I'm bringing part of myself to the story. Unless I'm TELLING a story. But no one's hiring for that.
You're now part of their process. You're in their system. And their system doesn't require/desire the writer as author but as craftsman.
You're just a story functionary from their POV--you're there to provide a service for them. No one cares if you have a story to tell.
But authorship is the other accelerator here. If u get hired to write "their project
column4:
you've already ceded the right as primary storyteller

Wbtv gave all S1 shows SAME budget. TSCC
column4: Pushing Daisies
column6: Big Shots. 2.65m. Think of how different the demands of those shows are.

text: I recall wbtv exec on TSCC telling me no tv show was ever improved by having a higher budget. I'd love to hear him say that to JN/LJ on WW.
And the avg. # of eps per season has dropped dramatically. As have residuals based on reruns. Hence our current situation.
10 yrs ago TSCC ep budget was 2.65m per. The writers budget was 100k/ep. Now budgets can be 4-5m. Writers budgets are still 100k.
Our job is to make the best out of whatever system we have. But the expectations for peak tv are high
column4: and our $ situation is getting worse.

text: Writers fret these things all the time. It's not rhetoric. We want to make the best things we can. And the system will never be perfect
So when you see WGA fighting for $ it really is because these $ issues are entwined in how we do our jobs. How we make great things.
Most showrunners fear they're going to be fired (cuz a lot are). Like a new football coach afraid to develop a young qb for next coach.
